Problem:
Consider a linear system characterized by the differential equations set \\(\\frac{d}{dt}x(t) = Ax(t) + b\\) where A is a linear operator and b is a constant vector. An integral transformation is defined by \\( f(x) = \\int_0^T e^{At}x(t) dt \\) for a time period T.

If at time \\( t_1 \\), an intervention redefines the system to \\(\\frac{d}{dt}x(t) = Dx(t) + c\\) when both D and c are constant, will the endpoint \\( f(x) \\) at T rely only on the initial setup (A, b) and not on the intervention (D, c)?
Explanation: The intervention changes the dynamics through both D and c, which will affect how the state evolves post-intervention. The transformed function output \\( f(x) \\) will therefore reflect the cumulative effects of both the original system defined by A, b and the new system defined by D, c, impacting the result at T.
